CatDescriptText: Mrs. Leon Blackston, housewife, 7121 Mr. Vernon Street and Mr. C.V. Edelin, postal transport worker of 1459 Newton Street, Washington, D.C., were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper December 5, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that Negroes should press in the fight for civil rights, or should they seek them through such medium as conciliation, persuasion and patience?" Mrs. Leon Blackston's answer reads: "Sometimes, patience takes forever.  Therefore, we should press a little and let them know that we are not satisfied with what has been given."  Mr. C.V. Edelin's answer reads: "Press.  We have been waiting for years for civil rights...In the last few years, since we have been pressing, we have made more progress than we did in the previous 25 years."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Mrs. Leon Blackston wearing dark coat with decorative buttons on collar, holding paper bag, standing with young girl in front of concrete block wall; Portrait of C.V. Edelin wearing light colored trench coat, standing in front of concrete block wall
